        \PYG{n+nv}{ynorm} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{ynorm} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nb}{abs}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{y}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp end parallel}

    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"norm of x = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{norm}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"  n(n+1)/2 = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'ynorm should be 1.0:   ynorm = '}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ynorm}

\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{main}
\end{Verbatim}

Note the following:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
We initialize $x_i=i$ as a test, so $\|x\|_1 = n(n+1)/2$.

\item {} 
The compiler decides how to split the loop between threads.
The loop starting on line 38 might be split differently than the
loop starting on line 45.

\item {} 
Because of this, all threads must have access to all of memory.

\end{itemize}

Next is a version with \emph{coarse-grain parallelism}, were we decide how to
split up the array between threads and then execute the same code on each
thread, but each thread will compute its own version of \emph{istart} and \emph{iend}
for its portion of the array.  With this code we are guaranteed that
thread 0 always handles \emph{x(1)}, for example, so in principle the data could
be distributed.  When using OpenMP on a shared memory computer this doesn't
matter, but this version is more easily generalized to MPI.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{! \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/openmp/normalize2.f90}

\PYG{c}{! Example of normalizing a vector using coarse-grain parallelism.}

\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{main}
    
    \PYG{k}{use }\PYG{n+nv}{omp\PYGZus{}lib}
    \PYG{k}{implicit }\PYG{k}{none}
\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k+kt}{integer}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{parameter} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{n} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1000}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{dimension}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{y}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{norm}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{norm\PYGZus{}thread}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{ynorm}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{ynorm\PYGZus{}thread}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{nthreads}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}thread}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{thread\PYGZus{}num}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{iend}

    \PYG{c}{! Specify number of threads to use:}
    \PYG{n+nv}{nthreads} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}       \PYG{c}{! need this value in serial mode}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{} nthreads = 4    }
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{} call omp\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}num\PYGZus{}threads(nthreads)}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{} print "('Using OpenMP with ',i3,' threads')", nthreads}

    \PYG{c}{! Determine how many points to handle with each thread.}
    \PYG{c}{! Note that dividing two integers and assigning to an integer will}
    \PYG{c}{! round down if the result is not an integer.  }
    \PYG{c}{! This, together with the min(...) in the definition of iend below,}
    \PYG{c}{! insures that all points will get distributed to some thread.}
    \PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}thread} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{nthreads} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n+nv}{nthreads}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}thread = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}thread}

    \PYG{c}{! initialize x:}
    \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}
        \PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{dble}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}  \PYG{c}{! convert to double float}
        \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

    \PYG{n+nv}{norm} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}
    \PYG{n+nv}{ynorm} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}

    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp parallel private(i,norm\PYGZus{}thread, \&}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp                  istart,iend,thread\PYGZus{}num,ynorm\PYGZus{}thread) }

    \PYG{n+nv}{thread\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}     \PYG{c}{! needed in serial mode}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{} thread\PYGZus{}num = omp\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}thread\PYGZus{}num()    ! unique for each thread}

    \PYG{c}{! Determine start and end index for the set of points to be }
    \PYG{c}{! handled by this thread:}
    \PYG{n+nv}{istart} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{thread\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}thread} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
    \PYG{n+nv}{iend} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{min}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{thread\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}thread}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp critical}
    \PYG{k}{print }\PYG{l+m+mi}{201}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{thread\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{iend}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp end critical}
\PYG{l+m+mi}{201} \PYG{k}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"Thread "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{i2}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+s+s2}{" will take i = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{i6}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+s+s2}{" through i = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{i6}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{n+nv}{norm\PYGZus{}thread} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}
    \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{iend}
        \PYG{n+nv}{norm\PYGZus{}thread} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{norm\PYGZus{}thread} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nb}{abs}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

    \PYG{c}{! update global norm with value from each thread:}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp critical}
      \PYG{n+nv}{norm} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{norm} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{norm\PYGZus{}thread}
      \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"norm updated to: "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{norm}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp end critical}

    \PYG{c}{! make sure all have updated norm before proceeding:}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp barrier}

    \PYG{n+nv}{ynorm\PYGZus{}thread} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}
    \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{iend}
        \PYG{n+nv}{y}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n+nv}{norm}
        \PYG{n+nv}{ynorm\PYGZus{}thread} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{ynorm\PYGZus{}thread} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nb}{abs}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{y}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

    \PYG{c}{! update global ynorm with value from each thread:}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp critical}
      \PYG{n+nv}{ynorm} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{ynorm} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{ynorm\PYGZus{}thread}
      \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"ynorm updated to: "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{ynorm}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp end critical}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp barrier}

    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp end parallel }

    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"norm of x = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{norm}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"  n(n+1)/2 = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'ynorm should be 1.0:   ynorm = '}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ynorm}

\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{main}
\end{Verbatim}

Note the following:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\emph{istart} and \emph{iend}, the starting and ending values of \emph{i}
taken by each thread, are explicitly computed in terms of the thread
number.  We must be careful to handle the case when the number of
threads does not evenly divide \emph{n}.

\item {} 
Various variables must be declared \emph{private} in lines 37-38.

\item {} 
\emph{norm} must be initialized to 0 before the \emph{omp parallel} block.
Otherwise some thread might set it to 0 after another thread has already
updated it by its \emph{norm\_thread}.

\item {} 
The update to \emph{norm}  on line 60
must be in a \emph{omp critical} block, so two threads
don't try to update it simultaneously (data race).

\item {} 
There must be an \emph{omp barrier} on line 65
between updating \emph{norm} by each thread and
using \emph{norm} to compute each \emph{y(i)}.   We must make sure all threads have
updated \emph{norm} or it won't have the correct value when we use it.

\end{itemize}

For comparison of fine-grain and
coarse-grain parallelism on Jacobi iteration, see
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
{\hyperref[jacobi1d_omp1:jacobi1d-omp1]{\emph{Jacobi iteration using OpenMP with parallel do constructs}}}

\item {} 
{\hyperref[jacobi1d_omp2:jacobi1d-omp2]{\emph{Jacobi iteration using OpenMP with coarse-grain parallel block}}}

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Further reading}
\label{openmp:further-reading}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
{\hyperref[biblio:biblio-openmp]{\emph{OpenMP references}}} in bibliography

\end{itemize}


\section{MPI}
\label{mpi:id1}\label{mpi::doc}\label{mpi:mpi}
MPI stands for \emph{Message Passing Interface} and is a standard approach for
programming distributed memory machines such as clusters, supercomputers, or
heterogeneous networks of computers.  It can also be used on a single
shared memory computer, although it is often more cumbersome to program in
MPI than in OpenMP.


\subsection{MPI implementations}
\label{mpi:mpi-implementations}
A number of different implementations are available (open source and vendor
supplied for specific machines).   See
\href{http://www.mcs.anl.gov/research/projects/mpi/implementations.html}{this list}, for
example.


\subsection{MPI on the class VM}
\label{mpi:mpi-on-the-class-vm}
The VM has \href{http://www.open-mpi.org/}{open-mpi}  partially installed.

You will need to do the following:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\$ sudo apt-get update
\$ sudo apt-get install openmpi-dev
\end{Verbatim}

On other Ubuntu installations you will also have to do:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\$ sudo apt-get install openmpi-bin          \# Already on the VM
\end{Verbatim}

You should then be able to do the following:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\$ cd \$UWHPSC/codes/mpi
\$ mpif90 test1.f90
\$ mpiexec -n 4 a.out
\end{Verbatim}

and see output like:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Hello from Process number           1  of            4  processes
Hello from Process number           3  of            4  processes
Hello from Process number           0  of            4  processes
Hello from Process number           2  of            4  processes
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{Test code}
\label{mpi:test-code}
The simple test code used above illustrates use of some of the basic MPI
subroutines.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{! \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/mpi/test1.f90}

\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{test1}
    \PYG{k}{use }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi}
    \PYG{k}{implicit }\PYG{k}{none}
\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{numprocs}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}

    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}comm\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{numprocs}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}comm\PYGZus{}rank}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'Hello from Process number'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
             \PYG{l+s+s1}{' of '}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{numprocs}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{' processes'}

    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}finalize}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{test1}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{Reduction example}
\label{mpi:reduction-example}
The next example uses \emph{MPI\_REDUCE} to add up partial sums computed by
independent processes.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{! \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/mpi/pisum1.f90}

\PYG{c}{! Computes pi using MPI.  }
\PYG{c}{! Compare to \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/openmp/pisum2.f90 }

\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{pisum1}
    \PYG{k}{use }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi}
    \PYG{k}{implicit }\PYG{k}{none}
\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{numprocs}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}proc}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
               \PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{iend}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{dx}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{pisum}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{pisum\PYGZus{}proc}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{pi}

    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}comm\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{numprocs}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}comm\PYGZus{}rank}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{c}{! Ask the user for the number of points}
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Using "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{numprocs}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+s+s2}{" processors"}
        \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Input n ... "}
        \PYG{k}{read} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{n}
    \PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{if}

    \PYG{c}{! Broadcast to all procs; everybody gets the value of n from proc 0}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}bcast}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}INTEGER}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{n+nv}{dx} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n+nv}{n}

    \PYG{c}{! Determine how many points to handle with each proc}
    \PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}proc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{numprocs} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n+nv}{numprocs}
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}   \PYG{c}{! Only one proc should print to avoid clutter}
        \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}proc = "}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}proc}
    \PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{if}

    \PYG{c}{! Determine start and end index for this proc's points}
    \PYG{n+nv}{istart} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}proc} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
    \PYG{n+nv}{iend} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{min}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}proc}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{c}{! Diagnostic: tell the user which points will be handled by which proc}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'("Process ",i2," will take i = ",i6," through i = ",i6)'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
          \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{iend}

    \PYG{n+nv}{pisum\PYGZus{}proc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}
    \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{iend}
        \PYG{n+nv}{x} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.5}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nv}{dx}
        \PYG{n+nv}{pisum\PYGZus{}proc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{pisum\PYGZus{}proc} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{o}{**}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}REDUCE}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{pisum\PYGZus{}proc}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{pisum}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}SUM}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                        \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{n+nv}{pi} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{4.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n+nv}{dx} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n+nv}{pisum} 
        \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"The approximation to pi is "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{pi}
        \PYG{k}{endif}

\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}finalize}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{pisum1}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{Send-Receive example}
\label{mpi:send-receive-example}
In this example, a value is set in Process 0 and then passed to Process 1
and on to Process 2, etc. until it reaches the last process, where it is
printed out.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{! \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/mpi/copyvalue.f90}
\PYG{c}{!}
\PYG{c}{! Set value in Process 0 and copy this through a chain of processes}
\PYG{c}{! and finally print result from Process numprocs-1.}
\PYG{c}{!}

\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{copyvalue}

    \PYG{k}{use }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi}

    \PYG{k}{implicit }\PYG{k}{none}

\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{num\PYGZus{}procs}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{dimension}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}STATUS\PYGZus{}SIZE}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{status}

    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}INIT}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}SIZE}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{num\PYGZus{}procs}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}RANK}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{num\PYGZus{}procs}\PYG{o}{==}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Only one process, cannot do anything"}
        \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}FINALIZE}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{k}{stop}
\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{endif}


\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{o}{==}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{n+nv}{i} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{55}
        \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'("Process ",i3," setting      i = ",i3)'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{i}

        \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}SEND}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}INTEGER}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{21}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                      \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

      \PYG{k}{else }\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{\textless{}} \PYG{n+nv}{num\PYGZus{}procs} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}

\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}RECV}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}INTEGER}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{21}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                      \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{status}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

        \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'("Process ",i3," receives     i = ",i3)'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{i}
        \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'("Process ",i3," sends        i = ",i3)'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{i}

        \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}SEND}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}INTEGER}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{21}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                      \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}


      \PYG{k}{else }\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{n+nv}{num\PYGZus{}procs} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}

\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}RECV}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}INTEGER}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{21}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                      \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{status}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

        \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'("Process ",i3," ends up with i = ",i3)'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{i}
      \PYG{k}{endif}

\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}FINALIZE}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{copyvalue}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{Master-worker examples}
\label{mpi:master-worker-examples}
The next two examples illustrate using Process 0 as a \emph{master} process to
farm work out to the other processes.  In both cases the 1-norm of a matrix
is computed, which is the maximum over \emph{j} of the 1-norm of the {\color{red}\bfseries{}{}`}j{}`th column
of the matrix.

In the first case we assume there are the same number of worker processes as
columns in the matrix:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{! \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/mpi/matrix1norm1.f90}
\PYG{c}{!}
\PYG{c}{! Compute 1-norm of a matrix using mpi.}
\PYG{c}{! Process 0 is the master that sets things up and then sends a column}
\PYG{c}{! to each worker (Processes 1, 2, ..., num\PYGZus{}procs - 1).}
\PYG{c}{!}
\PYG{c}{! This version assumes there are at least as many workers as columns.}

\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{matrix1norm1}

    \PYG{k}{use }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi}

    \PYG{k}{implicit }\PYG{k}{none}

\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{jj}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{nrows}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{ncols}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{num\PYGZus{}procs}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{nerr}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{dimension}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}STATUS\PYGZus{}SIZE}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{status}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{colnorm}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{allocatable}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{dimension}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{a}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{allocatable}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{dimension}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{anorm}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{colvect}

    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}INIT}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}SIZE}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{num\PYGZus{}procs}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}RANK}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{n+nv}{nerr} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{o}{==}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Input nrows, ncols"}
        \PYG{k}{read} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{nrows}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ncols}
        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ncols} \PYG{o}{\textgreater{}} \PYG{n+nv}{num\PYGZus{}procs}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{            }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"*** Error, this version requires ncols \textless{} num\PYGZus{}procs = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{p}{\&}
                  \PYG{n+nv}{num\PYGZus{}procs}
            \PYG{n+nv}{nerr} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
            \PYG{k}{endif}
\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{allocate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{a}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{nrows}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{ncols}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}  \PYG{c}{! only master process 0 needs the matrix}
        \PYG{n+nv}{a} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}  \PYG{c}{! initialize to all 1's for this test}
        \PYG{k}{allocate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{anorm}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ncols}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}    \PYG{c}{! to hold norm of each column in MPI\PYGZus{}RECV}
        \PYG{k}{endif}

    \PYG{c}{! if nerr == 1 then all processes must stop:}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}BCAST}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{nerr}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{nerr} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
        \PYG{c}{! Note that error message already printed by Process 0}
        \PYG{c}{! All processes must execute the MPI\PYGZus{}FINALIZE }
        \PYG{c}{! (Could also just have "go to 99" here.)}
        \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}FINALIZE}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{k}{stop}
\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{endif}
\PYG{k}{        }
\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}BCAST}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{nrows}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}BCAST}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ncols}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{\textgreater{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{allocate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{colvect}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{nrows}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}   \PYG{c}{! to hold a column vector sent from master}
        \PYG{k}{endif} 


    
    \PYG{c}{! -----------------------------------------}
    \PYG{c}{! code for Master (Processor 0):}
    \PYG{c}{! -----------------------------------------}

    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}

\PYG{k}{      }\PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{ncols}
        \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}SEND}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{a}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{nrows}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{p}{\&}
                        \PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

      \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{ncols}
        \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}RECV}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{colnorm}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                        \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}ANY\PYGZus{}SOURCE}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}ANY\PYGZus{}TAG}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                        \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{status}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{jj} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{status}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}TAG}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{anorm}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{jj}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{colnorm}
        \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

      \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Finished filling anorm with values... "}
      \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{anorm}
      \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"1-norm of matrix a = "}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{maxval}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{anorm}\PYG{p}{)}
      \PYG{k}{endif}


    \PYG{c}{! -----------------------------------------}
    \PYG{c}{! code for Workers (Processors 1, 2, ...):}
    \PYG{c}{! -----------------------------------------}
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}

\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{\textgreater{}} \PYG{n+nv}{ncols}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n+nv}{go} \PYG{n+nv}{to} \PYG{l+m+mi}{99}   \PYG{c}{! no work expected}

        \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}RECV}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{colvect}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{nrows}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{p}{\&}
                      \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}ANY\PYGZus{}TAG}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                      \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{status}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

        \PYG{n+nv}{j} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{status}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}TAG}\PYG{p}{)}   \PYG{c}{! this is the column number}
                              \PYG{c}{! (should agree with proc\PYGZus{}num)}

        \PYG{n+nv}{colnorm} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{sum}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{abs}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{colvect}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

        \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}SEND}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{colnorm}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                    \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

        \PYG{k}{endif}

\PYG{l+m+mi}{99}  \PYG{k}{continue}   \PYG{c}{! might jump to here if finished early}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}FINALIZE}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{matrix1norm1}
\end{Verbatim}

In the next case we consider the more realistic situation where there may be
many more columns in the matrix than worker processes.  In this case the
\emph{master} process must do more work to keep track of how which columns have
already been handled and farm out work as worker processes become free.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{! \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/mpi/matrix1norm2.f90}
\PYG{c}{!}
\PYG{c}{! Compute 1-norm of a matrix using mpi.}
\PYG{c}{! Process 0 is the master that sets things up and then sends a column}
\PYG{c}{! to each worker (Processes 1, 2, ..., num\PYGZus{}procs - 1).}
\PYG{c}{!}
\PYG{c}{! This version allows more columns than workers.}

\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{matrix1norm2}

    \PYG{k}{use }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi}

    \PYG{k}{implicit }\PYG{k}{none}

\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{jj}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{nrows}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{ncols}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{num\PYGZus{}procs}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{nerr}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{numsent}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{sender}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{nextcol}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{dimension}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}STATUS\PYGZus{}SIZE}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{status}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{colnorm}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{allocatable}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{dimension}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{a}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{allocatable}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{dimension}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{anorm}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{colvect}

    \PYG{k+kt}{logical} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{debug}

    \PYG{n+nv}{debug} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{.true.}

    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}INIT}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}SIZE}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{num\PYGZus{}procs}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}RANK}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{o}{==}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Input nrows, ncols"}
        \PYG{k}{read} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{nrows}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ncols}
        \PYG{k}{allocate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{a}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{nrows}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{ncols}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}  \PYG{c}{! only master process 0 needs the matrix}
        \PYG{n+nv}{a} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}  \PYG{c}{! initialize to all 1's for this test}
        \PYG{k}{allocate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{anorm}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ncols}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}    \PYG{c}{! to hold norm of each column in MPI\PYGZus{}RECV}
        \PYG{k}{endif}

\PYG{k}{        }
\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}BCAST}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{nrows}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}BCAST}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ncols}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{\textgreater{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{allocate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{colvect}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{nrows}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}   \PYG{c}{! to hold a column vector sent from master}
        \PYG{k}{endif} 


    
    \PYG{c}{! -----------------------------------------}
    \PYG{c}{! code for Master (Processor 0):}
    \PYG{c}{! -----------------------------------------}

    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}

\PYG{k}{      }\PYG{n+nv}{numsent} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0} \PYG{c}{! keep track of how many columns sent}

      \PYG{c}{! send the first batch to get all workers working:}
      \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nb}{min}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{num\PYGZus{}procs}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ncols}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}SEND}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{a}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{nrows}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{p}{\&}
                        \PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{numsent} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{numsent} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
        \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

      \PYG{c}{! as results come back, send out more work...}
      \PYG{c}{! the variable sender tells who sent back a result and ready for more}
      \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{ncols}
        \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}RECV}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{colnorm}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                        \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}ANY\PYGZus{}SOURCE}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}ANY\PYGZus{}TAG}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                        \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{status}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{sender} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{status}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}SOURCE}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{jj} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{status}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}TAG}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{anorm}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{jj}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{colnorm}

        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{numsent} \PYG{o}{\textless{}} \PYG{n+nv}{ncols}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
            \PYG{c}{! still more work to do, the next column will be sent and}
            \PYG{c}{! this index also used as the tag:}
            \PYG{n+nv}{nextcol} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{numsent} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1} 
            \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}SEND}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{a}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{nextcol}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{nrows}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{p}{\&}
                            \PYG{n+nv}{sender}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{nextcol}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n+nv}{numsent} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{numsent} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
          \PYG{k}{else}
            \PYG{c}{! send an empty message with tag=0 to indicate this worker}
            \PYG{c}{! is done:}
            \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}SEND}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}BOTTOM}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{p}{\&}
                            \PYG{n+nv}{sender}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
          \PYG{k}{endif}
\PYG{k}{            }
\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

      \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Finished filling anorm with values... "}
      \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{anorm}
      \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"1-norm of matrix a = "}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{maxval}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{anorm}\PYG{p}{)}
      \PYG{k}{endif}


    \PYG{c}{! -----------------------------------------}
    \PYG{c}{! code for Workers (Processors 1, 2, ...):}
    \PYG{c}{! -----------------------------------------}
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}

\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{\textgreater{}} \PYG{n+nv}{ncols}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n+nv}{go} \PYG{n+nv}{to} \PYG{l+m+mi}{99}   \PYG{c}{! no work expected}

        \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{k}{while} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{.true.}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{c}{! repeat until message with tag==0 received...}

            \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}RECV}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{colvect}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{nrows}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{p}{\&}
                          \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}ANY\PYGZus{}TAG}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                          \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{status}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{n+nv}{j} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{status}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}TAG}\PYG{p}{)}   \PYG{c}{! this is the column number}
                                  \PYG{c}{! may not be proc\PYGZus{}num in general}

            \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{debug}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{                }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'("+++ Process ",i4,"  received message with tag ",i6)'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                    \PYG{n+nv}{proc\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{j}       
                \PYG{k}{endif}

\PYG{k}{            }\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{o}{==}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n+nv}{go} \PYG{n+nv}{to} \PYG{l+m+mi}{99}    \PYG{c}{! received "done" message}

            \PYG{n+nv}{colnorm} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{sum}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{abs}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{colvect}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}SEND}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{colnorm}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                        \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}
        \PYG{k}{endif}

\PYG{l+m+mi}{99}  \PYG{k}{continue}   \PYG{c}{! might jump to here if finished early}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}FINALIZE}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{matrix1norm2}
\end{Verbatim}

\chapter{Miscellaneous}
\label{index:miscellaneous}\label{index:toc-misc}

\section{Makefiles}
\label{makefiles::doc}\label{makefiles:makefiles}\label{makefiles:id1}
The directory \emph{\$UWHPSC/codes/fortran/multifile1} contains a Fortran code
\emph{fullcode.f90} that consists of a main program and two subroutines:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{! \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/fortran/multifile1/fullcode.f90}

\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{demo}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"In main program"}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{sub1}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{sub2}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{demo}

\PYG{k}{subroutine }\PYG{n+nv}{sub1}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"In sub1"}
\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{subroutine }\PYG{n+nv}{sub1}

\PYG{k}{subroutine }\PYG{n+nv}{sub2}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"In sub2"}
\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{subroutine }\PYG{n+nv}{sub2}
\end{Verbatim}

To illustrate the construction of a Makefile, we first break this up into
three separate files:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{! \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/fortran/multifile1/main.f90}

\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{demo}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"In main program"}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{sub1}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{sub2}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{demo}
\end{Verbatim}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{! \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/fortran/multifile1/sub1.f90}

\PYG{k}{subroutine }\PYG{n+nv}{sub1}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"In sub1"}
\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{subroutine }\PYG{n+nv}{sub1}
\end{Verbatim}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{! \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/fortran/multifile1/sub2.f90}

\PYG{k}{subroutine }\PYG{n+nv}{sub2}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"In sub2"}
\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{subroutine }\PYG{n+nv}{sub2}
\end{Verbatim}

The directory \emph{\$UWHPSC/codes/fortran/multifile1} contains several Makefiles
that get successively more sophisticated to compile the codes in this
directory.

In the first version we write out explicitly what to do for each file:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/fortran/multifile1/Makefile}

\PYG{n+nf}{output.txt}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+m}{main.exe}
	./main.exe \textgreater{} output.txt

\PYG{n+nf}{main.exe}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+m}{main.o sub1.o sub2.o}
	gfortran main.o sub1.o sub2.o -o main.exe

\PYG{n+nf}{main.o}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+m}{main.f90}
	gfortran -c main.f90
\PYG{n+nf}{sub1.o}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+m}{sub1.f90}
	gfortran -c sub1.f90
\PYG{n+nf}{sub2.o}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+m}{sub2.f90}
	gfortran -c sub2.f90
\end{Verbatim}

In the second version there is a general rule for creating \emph{.o} files from
\emph{.f90} files:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/fortran/multifile1/Makefile2}

\PYG{n+nf}{output.txt}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+m}{main.exe}
	./main.exe \textgreater{} output.txt

\PYG{n+nf}{main.exe}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+m}{main.o sub1.o sub2.o}
	gfortran main.o sub1.o sub2.o -o main.exe

\PYG{n+nf}{\PYGZpc{}.o }\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+m}{\PYGZpc{}.f90}
	gfortran -c \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}\textless{}}
\end{Verbatim}

In the third version we define a macro \emph{OBJECTS} so we only have to write
out this list once, which minimizes the chance of introducing errors:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/fortran/multifile1/Makefile3}

\PYG{n+nv}{OBJECTS} \PYG{o}{=} main.o sub1.o sub2.o

output.txt: main.exe
	./main.exe \textgreater{} output.txt

main.exe: \PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}OBJECTS\PYG{k}{)}
	gfortran \PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}OBJECTS\PYG{k}{)} -o main.exe

\PYGZpc{}.o : \PYGZpc{}.f90
	gfortran -c \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}\textless{}}
\end{Verbatim}

In the fourth version, we add a Fortran compile flag (for level 3
optimization) and an linker flag (blank in this example):

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/fortran/multifile1/Makefile4}

\PYG{n+nv}{FC} \PYG{o}{=} gfortran    
\PYG{n+nv}{FFLAGS} \PYG{o}{=} -O3
\PYG{n+nv}{LFLAGS} \PYG{o}{=}
\PYG{n+nv}{OBJECTS} \PYG{o}{=} main.o sub1.o sub2.o

output.txt: main.exe
	./main.exe \textgreater{} output.txt

main.exe: \PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}OBJECTS\PYG{k}{)}
	\PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}FC\PYG{k}{)} \PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}LFLAGS\PYG{k}{)} \PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}OBJECTS\PYG{k}{)} -o main.exe

\PYGZpc{}.o : \PYGZpc{}.f90
	\PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}FC\PYG{k}{)} \PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}FFLAGS\PYG{k}{)} -c \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}\textless{}}
\end{Verbatim}

Next we add a \emph{phony} target \emph{clean}
that removes the files created when compiling
the code in order to facilitate cleanup.  It is \emph{phony} because it does not
create a file named \emph{clean}.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/fortran/multifile1/Makefile5}

\PYG{n+nv}{OBJECTS} \PYG{o}{=} main.o sub1.o sub2.o
.PHONY: clean

output.txt: main.exe
	./main.exe \textgreater{} output.txt

main.exe: \PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}OBJECTS\PYG{k}{)}
	gfortran \PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}OBJECTS\PYG{k}{)} -o main.exe

\PYGZpc{}.o : \PYGZpc{}.f90
	gfortran -c \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}\textless{}} 

clean:
	rm -f \PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}OBJECTS\PYG{k}{)} main.exe
\end{Verbatim}

Finally we add a help message so that \emph{make help} says something useful:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/fortran/multifile1/Makefile6}

\PYG{n+nv}{OBJECTS} \PYG{o}{=} main.o sub1.o sub2.o
.PHONY: clean \PYG{n+nb}{help}

output.txt: main.exe
	./main.exe \textgreater{} output.txt

main.exe: \PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}OBJECTS\PYG{k}{)}
	gfortran \PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}OBJECTS\PYG{k}{)} -o main.exe

\PYGZpc{}.o : \PYGZpc{}.f90
	gfortran -c \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}\textless{}} 

clean:
	rm -f \PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}OBJECTS\PYG{k}{)} main.exe

\PYG{n+nb}{help}:
	@echo \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Valid targets:"}
	@echo \PYG{l+s+s2}{"  main.exe"}
	@echo \PYG{l+s+s2}{"  main.o"}
	@echo \PYG{l+s+s2}{"  sub1.o"}
	@echo \PYG{l+s+s2}{"  sub2.o"}
	@echo \PYG{l+s+s2}{"  clean:  removes .o and .exe files"}
\end{Verbatim}

Fancier things are also possible, for example automatically detecting all
the \emph{.f90} files in the directory to construct the list of \emph{SOURCES}
and \emph{OBJECTS}:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/fortran/multifile1/Makefile7}

\PYG{n+nv}{SOURCES} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}wildcard *.f90\PYG{k}{)}  
\PYG{n+nv}{OBJECTS} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}subst .f90,.o,\PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}SOURCES\PYG{k}{)}\PYG{k}{)}

.PHONY: \PYG{n+nb}{test}

\PYG{n+nb}{test}:
	@echo \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Sources are: "} \PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}SOURCES\PYG{k}{)}
	@echo \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Objects are: "} \PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}OBJECTS\PYG{k}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

\section{Special functions}
\label{special_functions:special-functions}\label{special_functions::doc}\label{special_functions:id1}
There are many functions that are used so frequently that they are given
special names. Familiar examples are sin, cos, sqrt, exp, log, etc.

Most programming languages have build-in (intrinsic) functions with these
same names that can be called to compute the value of the function for
arbitrary arguments.

But ``under the hood'' these functions must be evaluated somehow.  The basic
arithmetic units of a computer are only capable of doing very basic
arithmetic in hardware: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.
Every other function must be \emph{approximated} by applying some sequence of
arithmetic operations.

There are several ways this might be done....


\subsection{Taylor series expansions}
\label{special_functions:taylor-series-expansions}
A finite number of terms in the Taylor series expansion of a function gives
a polynomial that approximates the desired function.  Polynomials can be
evaluated at any point using basic arithmetic.

For example, the section on {\hyperref[fortran_taylor:fortran-taylor]{\emph{Fortran examples: Taylor series}}} discusses an
implementation of the Taylor series approximation to the exponential
function,
\begin{quote}

$exp(x) = 1 + x + \frac 1 2 x ^2 + \frac 1 6 x^3 + \cdots$
\end{quote}

If this is truncated after the 4 terms shown, for example, we obtain a
polynomial of degree 3 that is easily evaluated at any point.

Some other Taylor series that can be used to approximate functions:
\begin{quote}

$sin(x) = x - \frac{1}{3!} x^3 + \frac 1 {5!} x^5 - \frac{1}{7!} x^7 + \cdots$

$cos(x) = 1 - \frac 1 2 x^2 + \frac{1}{4!} x^4 - \frac{1}{6!} x^6 + \cdots$
\end{quote}


\subsection{Newton's method for the square root}
\label{special_functions:newton-s-method-for-the-square-root}\label{special_functions:special-newton}
One way to evaluate the square root function is to use \emph{Newton's method}, a
general procedure for estimating a \emph{zero} of a function $f(x)$, i.e. a
value $x^*$ for which $f(x^*) = 0$.

The square root of any value $a>0$ is a zero of the function $f(x)
= x^2 - a$.  (This function has two zeros, at $\pm\sqrt{a}$.

Newton's method is based on taking a current estimate $x_k$ to
$x^*$ and (hopefully) improving it by setting
\begin{quote}

$x_{k+1} = x_k - \delta_k$
\end{quote}

The increment $\delta_k$ is determined by \emph{linearizing} the function
$f(x)$ about the current esimate $x_k$ using only the linear
term in the Taylor series expansion.  This linear function $G_k(x)$ is
\begin{quote}

$G_k(x) = f(x_k) + f'(x_k)(x-x_k)$.
\end{quote}

The next point $x_{k+1}$ is set to be the zero of this linear
function, which is trivial to find, and so
\begin{quote}

$\delta_k = f(x_k) / f'(x_k)$.
\end{quote}

Geometrically, this means that we move along the tangent line to
$f(x)$ from the point $(x_k,f(x_k))$ to the point where this
line hits the x-axis, at $(x_{k+1}, 0)$.  See the figures below.

There are several potential difficulties with this approach, e.g.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
To get started we require an \emph{initial guess} $x_0$.

\item {} 
The method may converge to a zero from some starting points but not
converge at all from others, or may converge to different zeros depending
on where we start.

\end{itemize}

For example, applying Newton's method to find a zero of $f(x) = x^2-2$
coverges to $\sqrt{2} \approx 1.414$ if we start at $x_0=0.5$,
but convergest o $-\sqrt{2} \approx -1.414$ if we start at
$x_0=-0.5$ as illustrated in the figures below.

\includegraphics[width=10cm]{newtonsqrt2m.png}

\includegraphics[width=10cm]{newtonsqrt2.png}

An advantage of Newton's method is that it is guaranteed to converge to a
root provided the function $f(x)$ is smooth enough and the starting
guess $x_0$ is sufficiently close to the zero.  Moreover, in general
one usually observes \emph{quadratic convergence}.  This means that once we get
close to the zero, the error roughly satisfies
\begin{quote}

$|x_{k+1} - x^*| \approx C|x_k-x^*|^2$
\end{quote}

The error is roughly squared in each step.  In practice this means that once
you have 2 correct digits in the solution, the next few steps will produce
approximations with roughly 4, 8, and 16 correct digits (doubling each
time), and so it rapidly converges to full machine precision.

For example, the approximations to $\sqrt{2}$ generated by Newton's
method starting at $x_0=0.5$ are:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
k, x, f(x):   1    0.500000000000000E+00   -0.175000E+01
k, x, f(x):   2    0.225000000000000E+01    0.306250E+01
k, x, f(x):   3    0.156944444444444E+01    0.463156E+00
k, x, f(x):   4    0.142189036381514E+01    0.217722E-01
k, x, f(x):   5    0.141423428594007E+01    0.586155E-04
k, x, f(x):   6    0.141421356252493E+01    0.429460E-09
k, x, f(x):   7    0.141421356237310E+01    0.444089E-15
\end{Verbatim}

The last value is correct to all digits.

There are many other methods that have been developed for finding zeros of
functions, and a number of software packages that are designed to be more
robust than Newton's method (less likely to fail to converge) while still
converging very rapidly.


\section{Timing code}
\label{timing:timing}\label{timing::doc}\label{timing:timing-code}

\subsection{Unix time command}
\label{timing:unix-time-command}\label{timing:timing-unix}
There is a built in command \emph{time} that can be used to time other commands.
Just type \emph{time command} at the prompt, e.g.:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\$ time ./a.out
\textless{}output from code\textgreater{}

real    0m5.279s
user    0m1.915s
sys     0m0.006s
\end{Verbatim}

This executes the command \emph{./a.out} in this case (running a Fortran
executable) and then prints information
about the time required to execute, where, roughly speaking,
\emph{real} is the wall-clock time, \emph{user} is the time spent executing the
user's program, and \emph{sys} is the time spent on system tasks required by the
program.

There may be a big difference between the \emph{real} time and the sum of the
other two times if the computer is simulataneously executing many other
tasks and your program is only getting some of its attention.

Using \emph{time} does not allow you to examine how much CPU time different parts
of the code required, for example.


\subsection{Fortran timing utilities}
\label{timing:timing-fortran}\label{timing:fortran-timing-utilities}
There are two Fortran intrinsic functions that are very useful.

\emph{system\_clock} tells the elapsed wall time between two successive calls, and
might be used as follows:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
integer(kind=8) :: tclock1, tclock2, clock\_rate
real(kind=8) :: elapsed\_time

call system\_clock(tclock1)

\textless{}code to be timed\textgreater{}

call system\_clock(tclock2, clock\_rate)
elapsed\_time = float(tclock2 - tclock1) / float(clock\_rate)
\end{Verbatim}

\emph{cpu\_time} tells the CPU time used between two successive calls:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
real(kind=8) :: t1, t2, elapsed\_cpu\_time

call cpu\_time(t1)

\textless{}code to be timed\textgreater{}

call cpu\_time(t2)
elapsed\_cpu\_time = t2 - t1
\end{Verbatim}

Here is an example code that uses both, and tests matrix-matrix multiply.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{! \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/fortran/optimize/timings.f90}

\PYG{c}{! Illustrate timing utilities in Fortran.}
\PYG{c}{!  system\PYGZus{}clock can be used to compute elapsed time between}
\PYG{c}{!      two calls (wall time)}
\PYG{c}{!  cpu\PYGZus{}time can be used to compute CPU time used between two calls.}

\PYG{c}{! Try compiling with different levels of optimization, e.g. -O3}


\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{timings}

    \PYG{k}{implicit }\PYG{k}{none}
\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k+kt}{integer}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{parameter} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{ntests} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{20}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{n} 
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{allocatable}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{dimension}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{a}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{b}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{c}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{t1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{t2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{elapsed\PYGZus{}time}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{tclock1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{tclock2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{clock\PYGZus{}rate}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{k}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{itest}

    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nb}{system\PYGZus{}clock}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{tclock1}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Will multiply n by n matrices, input n: "}
    \PYG{k}{read} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{n}

    \PYG{k}{allocate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{a}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{b}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{c}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{c}{! fill a and b with 1's just for demo purposes:}
    \PYG{n+nv}{a} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}
    \PYG{n+nv}{b} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}

    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nb}{cpu\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{t1}\PYG{p}{)}   \PYG{c}{! start cpu timer}
    \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{itest}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{ntests}
        \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{j} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}
            \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}
                \PYG{n+nv}{c}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}
                \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{k}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}
                    \PYG{n+nv}{c}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{c}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{a}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{k}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nv}{b}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{k}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{)}
                    \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}
                \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}
            \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}
        \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nb}{cpu\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{t2}\PYG{p}{)}   \PYG{c}{! end cpu timer}
    \PYG{k}{print }\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ntests}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{t2}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n+nv}{t1}
 \PYG{l+m+mi}{10} \PYG{k}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"Performed "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{i4}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{" matrix multiplies: CPU time = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{f12}\PYG{l+m+mf}{.8}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{" seconds"}\PYG{p}{)}

    
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nb}{system\PYGZus{}clock}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{tclock2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{clock\PYGZus{}rate}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n+nv}{elapsed\PYGZus{}time} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{float}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{tclock2} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{n+nv}{tclock1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n+nb}{float}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{clock\PYGZus{}rate}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{print }\PYG{l+m+mi}{11}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{elapsed\PYGZus{}time}
 \PYG{l+m+mi}{11} \PYG{k}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"Elapsed time = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{f12}\PYG{l+m+mf}{.8}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{" seconds"}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{timings}
\end{Verbatim}

Note that the matrix-matrix product is computed 20 times over to give a
better estimate of the timings.

You might want to experiment with this code and various sizes of the
matrices and optimization levels.  Here are a few sample results on a
MacBook Pro.

First, with no optimization and $200\times 200$ matrices:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\$ gfortran timings.f90
\$ ./a.out
 Will multiply n by n matrices, input n:
200
Performed   20 matrix multiplies: CPU time =   0.81523600 seconds
Elapsed time =   5.94083357 seconds
\end{Verbatim}

Note that the elapsed time include the time required to type in the response
to the prompt for \emph{n}, as well as the time required to allocate and
initialize the matrices, whereas the CPU time is just for the matrix
multiplication loops.

Trying a larger $400 \times 400$ case gives:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\$ ./a.out
 Will multiply n by n matrices, input n:
400
Performed   20 matrix multiplies: CPU time =   7.33721500 seconds
Elapsed time =   9.87114525 seconds
\end{Verbatim}

Since computing the product of $n \times n$ matrices takes
$O(n^3)$ flops,
we expect this to take about 8 times as much CPU time as the previous test.
This is roughly what we observe.

Doubling the size again gives requires much more that 8 times as long
however:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\$ ./a.out
 Will multiply n by n matrices, input n:
800
Performed   20 matrix multiplies: CPU time =  90.49682200 seconds
Elapsed time =  93.98917389 seconds
\end{Verbatim}

Note that 3 matrices that are $400\times 400$ require 3.84 MB of memory,
whereas three $800 \times 800$ matrices require 15.6 MB.  Since the MacBook
used for this experiment
has only 6 MB of L3 cache, the data no longer fit in cache.

\textbf{Compiling with optimization}

If we recompile with the -O3 optimization flag, the last two experiments
give these results:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\$ gfortran -O3 timings.f90
\$ ./a.out
 Will multiply n by n matrices, input n:
400
Performed   20 matrix multiplies: CPU time =   1.39002200 seconds
Elapsed time =   3.58041191 seconds
\end{Verbatim}

and

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\$ ./a.out
 Will multiply n by n matrices, input n:
800
Performed   20 matrix multiplies: CPU time =  66.39167200 seconds
Elapsed time =  68.29921722 seconds
\end{Verbatim}

Both have sped up relative to the un-optimized code, the first much more
dramatically.


\subsection{Timing OpenMP code}
\label{timing:timing-openmp-code}
The code in \emph{\$UWHPSC/codes/openmp/timings.f90} shows an analogous code for
matrix multiplication using OpenMP.

The code has been slightly modified so that \emph{system\_clock} is only timing
the inner loops in order to illustrate that \emph{cpu\_time} now computes the sum
of the CPU time of all threads.

Here's one sample result:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\$ gfortran -fopenmp -O3 timings.f90
\$ ./a.out
 Using OpenMP, how many threads?
4
 Will multiply n by n matrices, input n:
400
Performed   20 matrix multiplies: CPU time =   1.99064000 seconds
Elapsed time =   0.58711302 seconds
\end{Verbatim}

Note that the CPU time reported is nearly 2 seconds but the elapsed time is
only 0.58 seconds in this case when 4 threads are being used.

The total CPU time is slightly more than the previous code that did not use
OpenMP, but the wall time is considerably less.

For $800\times 800$ matrices there is a similar speedup:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\$ ./a.out
 Using OpenMP, how many threads?
4
 Will multiply n by n matrices, input n:
800
Performed   20 matrix multiplies: CPU time =  79.70573500 seconds
Elapsed time =  21.37633133 seconds
\end{Verbatim}

Here is the code:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{! \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/fortran/optimize/timings1.f90}

\PYG{c}{! Illustrate timing utilities in Fortran.}
\PYG{c}{!  system\PYGZus{}clock can be used to compute elapsed time between}
\PYG{c}{!      two calls (wall time)}
\PYG{c}{!  cpu\PYGZus{}time can be used to compute CPU time used between two calls.}

\PYG{c}{! Try compiling with different levels of optimization, e.g. -O3}


\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{timings1}

    \PYG{k}{use }\PYG{n+nv}{omp\PYGZus{}lib}

    \PYG{k}{implicit }\PYG{k}{none}
\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k+kt}{integer}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{parameter} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{ntests} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{20}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{nthreads}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{allocatable}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{dimension}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{a}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{b}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{c}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{t1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{t2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{elapsed\PYGZus{}time}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{tclock1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{tclock2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{clock\PYGZus{}rate}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{k}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{itest}

    \PYG{c}{! Specify number of threads to use:}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{} print *, "Using OpenMP, how many threads? "}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{} read *, nthreads }
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{} call omp\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}num\PYGZus{}threads(nthreads)}

    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Will multiply n by n matrices, input n: "}
    \PYG{k}{read} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{n}

    \PYG{k}{allocate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{a}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{b}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{c}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{c}{! fill a and b with 1's just for demo purposes:}
    \PYG{n+nv}{a} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}
    \PYG{n+nv}{b} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}

    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nb}{system\PYGZus{}clock}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{tclock1}\PYG{p}{)}  \PYG{c}{! start wall timer}

    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nb}{cpu\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{t1}\PYG{p}{)}   \PYG{c}{! start cpu timer}
    \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{itest}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{ntests}
        \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp parallel do private(i,k)}
        \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{j} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}
            \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}
                \PYG{n+nv}{c}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}
                \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{k}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}
                    \PYG{n+nv}{c}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{c}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{a}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{k}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nv}{b}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{k}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{j}\PYG{p}{)}
                    \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}
                \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}
            \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}
        \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nb}{cpu\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{t2}\PYG{p}{)}   \PYG{c}{! end cpu timer}
    \PYG{k}{print }\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ntests}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{t2}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n+nv}{t1}
 \PYG{l+m+mi}{10} \PYG{k}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"Performed "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{i4}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{" matrix multiplies: CPU time = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{f12}\PYG{l+m+mf}{.8}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{" seconds"}\PYG{p}{)}

    
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nb}{system\PYGZus{}clock}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{tclock2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{clock\PYGZus{}rate}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n+nv}{elapsed\PYGZus{}time} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{float}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{tclock2} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{n+nv}{tclock1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n+nb}{float}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{clock\PYGZus{}rate}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{print }\PYG{l+m+mi}{11}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{elapsed\PYGZus{}time}
 \PYG{l+m+mi}{11} \PYG{k}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"Elapsed time = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{f12}\PYG{l+m+mf}{.8}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{" seconds"}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{timings1}
\end{Verbatim}


\section{Linear Algebra software}

\subsection{The BLAS}
\label{linalg:blas}\label{linalg:the-blas}
The Basic Linear Algebra Subroutines are extensively used in LAPACK, in
other linear algebra packages, and elsewhere.

There are three levels of BLAS:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Level 1: Scalar and vector operations

\item {} 
Level 2: Matrix-vector operations

\item {} 
Level 3: Matrix-matrix operations

\end{itemize}

For general information about BLAS see
\href{http://www.netlib.org/blas/faq.html}{http://www.netlib.org/blas/faq.html}.

Optimized versions of the BLAS are available for many computer
architectures.  See
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\href{http://xianyi.github.io/OpenBLAS/}{OpenBLAS}

\item {} 
\href{http://www.tacc.utexas.edu/tacc-projects/gotoblas2}{GotoBLAS}

\end{itemize}

See also:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\href{http://math-atlas.sourceforge.net/}{Automatically Tuned Linear Algebra Software (ATLAS)}

\item {} 
\href{http://www.netlib.org/blacs/}{BLACS} Basic Linear Algebra Communication
Subprograms with message passing.

\item {} 
\href{http://www.ce.uniroma2.it/psblas/}{PSBLAS} -- Parallel sparse BLAS.

\end{itemize}
