\chapter{Applications}
\label{index:applications}\label{index:toc-apps}

\section{Numerical methods for the Poisson problem}
\label{poisson:numerical-methods-for-the-poisson-problem}\label{poisson::doc}\label{poisson:poisson}
The steady state diffusion equation gives rise to a \emph{Poisson problem}

$u_{xx} + u_{yy} = -f(x,y)$

where $f(x,y)$ is the source term.  In the simplest case
$f(x,y) = 0$ this reduces to \emph{Laplace's equation}.
This must be augmented with boundary conditions around the edge of some
two-dimensional region.  \emph{Dirchlet boundary conditions} consist of
specifying the solution $u(x,y)$ at all points around the boundary.
\emph{Neumann boundary conditions} consist of specifying the normal dirivative
(i.e. the direction derivative of the solution in the direction orthogonal
to the boundary) and are used in physical situations where the if the flux of
heat or the diffused quantity is known along the boundary rather than the
value of the solution itself (for example an \emph{insulated boundary} has no
flux and the normal derivative is zero).  We will only study Dirichlet
problems, where $u$ itself is known at boundary points.  We will also
concentrate on problems in a rectangular domain $a_x < x < b_x$ and
$a_y < y < b_y$, in which case it is natural to discretize
on a \emph{Cartesian grid} aligned with the axes.

The Poisson problem can be discretized on a two-dimensional Cartesian grid
with equal grid
spacing $h$ in the $x$ and $y$ directions as

$U_{i-1,j} + U_{i+1,j} + U_{i,j-1} + U_{i,j+1} - 4u_{ij} = -h^2
f(x_i,y_j)$.

This gives a coupled system of equations with $n_x n_y$ unknowns,
where it is assumed that $h(n_x+1) = b_x - a_x$ and
$h(n_y+1) = b_y - a_y$.  The linear system has a very sparse
coefficient matrix since each of the $n_x n_y$ rows has at most 5
nonzero entries.

If the boundary data varies smoothly around the boundary then it can be
shown that solving this linear system gives an approximate solution
of the partial differential equation that is ${\cal O}(h^2)$ accurate
each each point.  There are many books that contain much
more about the development and analysis of such finite difference methods.


\subsection{Iterative methods for the Poisson problem}
\label{poisson:poisson-iter}\label{poisson:iterative-methods-for-the-poisson-problem}
Simple iterative methods such as Jacobi, Gauss-Siedel, and Successive
Over-Relaxation (SOR) are discussed in the lectures and used a examples for
implementations in OpenMP and MPI.  For three implementation of Jacobi in
one space dimension, see
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
{\hyperref[jacobi1d_omp1:jacobi1d-omp1]{\emph{Jacobi iteration using OpenMP with parallel do constructs}}}

\item {} 
{\hyperref[jacobi1d_omp2:jacobi1d-omp2]{\emph{Jacobi iteration using OpenMP with coarse-grain parallel block}}}

\item {} 
{\hyperref[jacobi1d_mpi:jacobi1d-mpi]{\emph{Jacobi iteration using MPI}}}

\end{itemize}

For a sample implementation of Jacobi in two space dimensions can be found
in \emph{\$UWHPSC/lectures/lecture1}.


\subsection{Monte Carlo methods for the steady state diffusion equation}
\label{poisson:poisson-mc}\label{poisson:monte-carlo-methods-for-the-steady-state-diffusion-equation}
Solving the linear system described above would give an approximate solution
to the Poisson problem at each point on the grid.  Suppose we only want to
approximate the solution at a single point $(x_0,y_0)$ for some reason.
Is there a way
to estimate this without solving the system for all values $U_{ij}$?
Not easily from the linear system, but there are other approaches that might
be used.

We will consider a Monte Carlo approach in which a large number of
\emph{random walks} starting from the point of interest are used to estimate the
solution.  See {\hyperref[random:random]{\emph{Random number generators}}} for a discussion of random number generators
and Monte Carlo methods more generally.

We will assume there is no source term, $f(x,y)=0$ so that we are
solving Laplace's equation.  The random walk solution is more complicated if
there is a source term.

A random walk starting at some point $(x_0,y_0)$ wanders randomly in
the domain until it hits the boundary at some point.  We do this many times
over and keep track of the boundary value given for $u(x,y)$ at the
point where each walk hits the boundary.  It can be shown that if we do for
a large number of walks and average the results, this converges to the
desired solution value $u(x_0,y_0)$.  Note that we expect more walks
to to hit the boundary at parts of the boundary near $(x_0,y_0)$ than
at points further away, so the boundary conditions at such points will have
more influence on the solution.  This is intuitively what we expect for a
steady state solution of a diffusion or heat conduction problem.

To implement this numerically we will consider the simplification
of a \emph{lattice random walk}, in which we put down a grid on the domain as in
the finite difference discretization and allow the random walk to only go in
one of 4 directions in each time step, from a point on the grid to one of
its four neighbors.  For isotropic diffusion as we are considering,
we can define a random walk by choosing 1 of the four
neighbors with equal probability in each step.

The code \emph{\$UWHPSC/codes/project/laplace\_mc.py} illustrates this.
Run this code with
\emph{plot\_walk = True} to see plots of a few random walks on a coarse grid, or with
\emph{plot\_walk = False} to report the solution after many random walks on a finer
grid.

With this lattice random walk we do not expect the approximate solution to
converge to the true solution of the PDE, as the number of trials increases.
Instead we expect it to converge to the solution of the linear system
determined by the finite difference method described above.
In other words if we choose $(x_0,y_0) = (x_i, y_j)$ for some grid
point :math:`(i,j)$ then we expect the Monte Carlo solution to converge to
$U_{ij}$ rather than to $u(x_i,y_j)$.

\textbf{Why does this work?}  Here's one way to think about it.  Suppose doing this
random walk starting at $u(x_i,y_j)$ converges to some value $E_{ij}$,
the expected value of u at the boundary hit when starting a random walk at this
point.  If $(x_i,y_j)$ is one of the boundary points then
$E_{ij} = U_{ij}$ since we immediately hit the boundary with zero
steps, so every random walk starting at this point returns $u$ at this
point.  On the other hand, if $(x_i,y_j)$ is an interior point, then
after a single step of the random walk we will be at one of the four
neighbors.  Continuing our original random walk from this point is
equivalent to starting a new random walk at this point.  So for example
any random walk that first takes a step to the right from $(x_i,y_j)$
to $(x_{i+1},y_j)$ has the same expected boundary value as obtained
from all random walks starting at $(x_{i+1},y_j)$, i.e. the value
$E_{i+1,j}$.  But only 1/4 of the random walks starting at
$(x_i,y_j)$ go first to the right.  So the expected value over all
walks starting at $(x_i,y_j)$ is expected to be the average of the
expected value when starting at any of the 4 neighbors.  In other words,

$E_{ij} = \frac 1 4 (E_{i-1,j} + E_{i+1,j} + E_{i,j-1} + E_{i,j+1})$

But this means $E_{ij}$ satisfies the same linear system of equations
as $U_{ij}$ (and also the same boundary conditions),
and hence must be the same.


\section{Jacobi iteration using OpenMP with \emph{parallel do} constructs}
\label{jacobi1d_omp1:jacobi-iteration-using-openmp-with-parallel-do-constructs}\label{jacobi1d_omp1:jacobi1d-omp1}\label{jacobi1d_omp1::doc}
The code below implements Jacobi iteration for solving the linear system
arising from the steady state heat equation
with a simple application of \emph{parallel do} loops using OpenMP.

Compare to:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
{\hyperref[jacobi1d_omp2:jacobi1d-omp2]{\emph{Jacobi iteration using OpenMP with coarse-grain parallel block}}}

\item {} 
{\hyperref[jacobi1d_mpi:jacobi1d-mpi]{\emph{Jacobi iteration using MPI}}}

\end{itemize}

The code:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{! \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/openmp/jacobi1d\PYGZus{}omp1.f90}
\PYG{c}{!}
\PYG{c}{! Jacobi iteration illustrating fine grain parallelism with OpenMP.}
\PYG{c}{!}
\PYG{c}{! Several omp parallel do loops are used.  Each time threads will be}
\PYG{c}{! forked and the compiler will decide how to split up the loop.}

\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{jacobi1d\PYGZus{}omp1}
    \PYG{k}{use }\PYG{n+nv}{omp\PYGZus{}lib}
    \PYG{k}{implicit }\PYG{k}{none}
\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{nthreads}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{dimension}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{allocatable} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{f}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{alpha}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{beta}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{dx}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{tol}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{dumax}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{intrinsic} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nb}{exp}
\PYG{n+nb}{    }\PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{t1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{t2}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{iter}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{maxiter} 

    \PYG{c}{! Specify number of threads to use:}
    \PYG{n+nv}{nthreads} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{} call omp\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}num\PYGZus{}threads(nthreads)}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{} print "('Using OpenMP with ',i3,' threads')", nthreads}

    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Input n ... "}
    \PYG{k}{read} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{n}

    \PYG{c}{! allocate storage for boundary points too:}
    \PYG{k}{allocate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{f}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{k}{open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{unit}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{file}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"heatsoln.txt"}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{status}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"unknown"}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nb}{cpu\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{t1}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{c}{! grid spacing:}
    \PYG{n+nv}{dx} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{c}{! boundary conditions:}
    \PYG{n+nv}{alpha} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}
    \PYG{n+nv}{beta} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{6}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}

    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp parallel do}
    \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
        \PYG{c}{! grid points:}
        \PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nv}{dx}
        \PYG{c}{! source term:}
        \PYG{n+nv}{f}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nb}{exp}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{c}{! initial guess:}
        \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{alpha} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{beta}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n+nv}{alpha}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

    \PYG{c}{! tolerance and max number of iterations:}
    \PYG{n+nv}{tol} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.1} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n+nv}{dx}\PYG{o}{**}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Convergence tolerance: tol = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{tol}
    \PYG{n+nv}{maxiter} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100000}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Maximum number of iterations: maxiter = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{maxiter}

    \PYG{c}{! Jacobi iteratation:}

    \PYG{n+nv}{uold} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{u}  \PYG{c}{! starting values before updating}

    \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{iter}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{maxiter}
        \PYG{n+nv}{dumax} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}
        \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp parallel do reduction(max : dumax)}
        \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}
            \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.5}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{dx}\PYG{o}{**}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nv}{f}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n+nv}{dumax} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{max}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{dumax}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{abs}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}
        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{mod}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{iter}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10000}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{==}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{            }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{iter}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{dumax}
            \PYG{k}{endif}
        \PYG{c}{! check for convergence:}
        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{dumax} \PYG{o+ow}{.lt.} \PYG{n+nv}{tol}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{exit}

        \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp parallel do }
        \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}
            \PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}   \PYG{c}{! for next iteration}
            \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}
        \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

        \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nb}{cpu\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{t2}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'("CPU time = ",f12.8, " seconds")'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{t2}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n+nv}{t1}

        \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Total number of iterations: "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{iter}

    \PYG{k}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"          x                  u"}
    \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
        \PYG{k}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+s+s1}{'(2e20.10)'}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Solution is in heatsoln.txt"}


    \PYG{k}{close}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{jacobi1d\PYGZus{}omp1}
\end{Verbatim}


\section{Jacobi iteration using OpenMP with coarse-grain \emph{parallel} block}
\label{jacobi1d_omp2:jacobi1d-omp2}\label{jacobi1d_omp2::doc}\label{jacobi1d_omp2:jacobi-iteration-using-openmp-with-coarse-grain-parallel-block}
The code below implements Jacobi iteration for solving the linear system
arising from the steady state heat equation
with a single \emph{parallel} block.  Work is split up manually between threads.

Compare to:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
{\hyperref[jacobi1d_omp1:jacobi1d-omp1]{\emph{Jacobi iteration using OpenMP with parallel do constructs}}}

\item {} 
{\hyperref[jacobi1d_mpi:jacobi1d-mpi]{\emph{Jacobi iteration using MPI}}}

\end{itemize}

The code:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{! \PYGZdl{}UWHPSC/codes/openmp/jacobi1d\PYGZus{}omp2.f90}
\PYG{c}{!}
\PYG{c}{! Domain decomposition version of Jacobi iteration illustrating}
\PYG{c}{! coarse grain parallelism with OpenMP.}
\PYG{c}{!}
\PYG{c}{! The grid points are split up into nthreads disjoint sets and each thread}
\PYG{c}{! is assigned one set that it updates for all iterations.}

\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{jacobi1d\PYGZus{}omp2}
    \PYG{k}{use }\PYG{n+nv}{omp\PYGZus{}lib}
    \PYG{k}{implicit }\PYG{k}{none}
\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{dimension}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{allocatable} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{f}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{alpha}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{beta}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{dx}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{tol}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{dumax}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{dumax\PYGZus{}thread}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{intrinsic} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nb}{exp}
\PYG{n+nb}{    }\PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{t1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{t2}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{nthreads}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}thread}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{thread\PYGZus{}num}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{iter}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{maxiter}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{iend}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{nprint}

    \PYG{c}{! Specify number of threads to use:}
    \PYG{n+nv}{nthreads} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}       \PYG{c}{! need this value in serial mode}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{} nthreads = 2    }
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{} call omp\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}num\PYGZus{}threads(nthreads)}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{} print "('Using OpenMP with ',i3,' threads')", nthreads}

    \PYG{n+nv}{nprint} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10000} \PYG{c}{! print dumax every nprint iterations}

    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Input n ... "}
    \PYG{k}{read} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{n}

    \PYG{c}{! allocate storage for boundary points too:}
    \PYG{k}{allocate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{f}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{k}{open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{unit}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{file}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"heatsoln.txt"}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{status}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"unknown"}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nb}{cpu\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{t1}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{c}{! grid spacing:}
    \PYG{n+nv}{dx} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{c}{! boundary conditions:}
    \PYG{n+nv}{alpha} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}
    \PYG{n+nv}{beta} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{6}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}

    \PYG{c}{! tolerance and max number of iterations:}
    \PYG{n+nv}{tol} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.1} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n+nv}{dx}\PYG{o}{**}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Convergence tolerance: tol = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{tol}
    \PYG{n+nv}{maxiter} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100000}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Maximum number of iterations: maxiter = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{maxiter}

    \PYG{c}{! Determine how many points to handle with each thread.}
    \PYG{c}{! Note that dividing two integers and assigning to an integer will}
    \PYG{c}{! round down if the result is not an integer.  }
    \PYG{c}{! This, together with the min(...) in the definition of iend below,}
    \PYG{c}{! insures that all points will get distributed to some thread.}
    \PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}thread} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{nthreads} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n+nv}{nthreads}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}thread = "}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}thread}


    \PYG{c}{! Start of the parallel block... }
    \PYG{c}{! ------------------------------}

    \PYG{c}{! This is the only time threads are forked in this program:}

    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp parallel private(thread\PYGZus{}num, iter, istart, iend, i, dumax\PYGZus{}thread) }

    \PYG{n+nv}{thread\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}     \PYG{c}{! needed in serial mode}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{} thread\PYGZus{}num = omp\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}thread\PYGZus{}num()    ! unique for each thread}

    \PYG{c}{! Determine start and end index for the set of points to be }
    \PYG{c}{! handled by this thread:}
    \PYG{n+nv}{istart} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{thread\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}thread} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
    \PYG{n+nv}{iend} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{min}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{thread\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}thread}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp critical}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'("Thread ",i2," will take i = ",i6," through i = ",i6)'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
          \PYG{n+nv}{thread\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{iend}
    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp end critical}

    \PYG{c}{! Initialize:}
    \PYG{c}{! -----------}

    \PYG{c}{! each thread sets part of these arrays:}
    \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{iend}
        \PYG{c}{! grid points:}
        \PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nv}{dx}
        \PYG{c}{! source term:}
        \PYG{n+nv}{f}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nb}{exp}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{c}{! initial guess:}
        \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{alpha} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{beta}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n+nv}{alpha}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}
    
    \PYG{c}{! boundary conditions need to be added:}
    \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{alpha}
    \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{beta}

    \PYG{n+nv}{uold} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{u}   \PYG{c}{! initialize, including boundary values}


    \PYG{c}{! Jacobi iteratation:}
    \PYG{c}{! -------------------}


    \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{iter}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{maxiter}

        \PYG{c}{! initialize uold to u (note each thread does part!)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nv}{iend}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nv}{iend}\PYG{p}{)} 

        \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp single}
        \PYG{n+nv}{dumax} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}     \PYG{c}{! global max initialized by one thread}
        \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp end single}

        \PYG{c}{! Make sure all of uold is initialized before iterating}
        \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp barrier}
        \PYG{c}{! Make sure uold is consitent in memory:}
        \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp flush}

        \PYG{n+nv}{dumax\PYGZus{}thread} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}   \PYG{c}{! max seen by this thread}
        \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{iend}
            \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.5}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{dx}\PYG{o}{**}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nv}{f}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n+nv}{dumax\PYGZus{}thread} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{max}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{dumax\PYGZus{}thread}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{abs}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

        \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp critical}
        \PYG{c}{! update global dumax using value from this thread:}
        \PYG{n+nv}{dumax} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{max}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{dumax}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{dumax\PYGZus{}thread}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp end critical}

        \PYG{c}{! make sure all threads are done with dumax:}
        \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp barrier}

        \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp single}
        \PYG{c}{! only one thread will do this print statement:}
        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{mod}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{iter}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{nprint}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{==}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{            }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'("After ",i8," iterations, dumax = ",d16.6,/)'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{iter}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{dumax}
            \PYG{k}{endif}
        \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp end single}

        \PYG{c}{! check for convergence:}
        \PYG{c}{! note that all threads have same value of dumax }
        \PYG{c}{! at this point, so they will all exit on the same iteration.}
        
        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{dumax} \PYG{o+ow}{.lt.} \PYG{n+nv}{tol}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{exit}

        \PYG{c}{! need to synchronize here so no thread resets dumax = 0}
        \PYG{c}{! at start of next iteration before all have done the test above.}
        \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp barrier}

        \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'("Thread number ",i2," finished after ",i9, \&}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{            " iterations, dumax = ", e16.6)'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
          \PYG{n+nv}{thread\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{iter}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{dumax}

    \PYG{c}{!\PYGZdl{}omp end parallel}

    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nb}{cpu\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{t2}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'("CPU time = ",f12.8, " seconds")'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{t2}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n+nv}{t1}


    \PYG{c}{! Write solution to heatsoln.txt:}
    \PYG{k}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"          x                  u"}
    \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
        \PYG{k}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+s+s1}{'(2e20.10)'}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{enddo}

    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Solution is in heatsoln.txt"}

    \PYG{k}{close}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{jacobi1d\PYGZus{}omp2}
\end{Verbatim}


\section{Jacobi iteration using MPI}
\label{jacobi1d_mpi::doc}\label{jacobi1d_mpi:jacobi-iteration-using-mpi}\label{jacobi1d_mpi:jacobi1d-mpi}
The code below implements Jacobi iteration for solving the linear system
arising from the steady state heat equation
using MPI.  Note that in this code each process, or task, has only a portion
of the arrays and must exchange boundary data using message passing.

Compare to:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
{\hyperref[jacobi1d_omp1:jacobi1d-omp1]{\emph{Jacobi iteration using OpenMP with parallel do constructs}}}

\item {} 
{\hyperref[jacobi1d_omp2:jacobi1d-omp2]{\emph{Jacobi iteration using OpenMP with coarse-grain parallel block}}}

\end{itemize}

The code:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{! \PYGZdl{}UWHSPC/codes/mpi/jacobi1d\PYGZus{}mpi.f90}
\PYG{c}{!}
\PYG{c}{! Domain decomposition version of Jacobi iteration illustrating}
\PYG{c}{! coarse grain parallelism with MPI.}
\PYG{c}{!}
\PYG{c}{! The one-dimensional Poisson problem is solved, u''(x) = -f(x)}
\PYG{c}{! with u(0) = alpha and u(1) = beta.}
\PYG{c}{!}
\PYG{c}{! The grid points are split up into ntasks disjoint sets and each task}
\PYG{c}{! is assigned one set that it updates for all iterations.  The tasks }
\PYG{c}{! correspond to processes.}
\PYG{c}{!}
\PYG{c}{! The task (or process) number is called "me" in this code for brevity}
\PYG{c}{! rather than proc\PYGZus{}num.}
\PYG{c}{!}
\PYG{c}{! Note that each task allocates only as much storage as needed for its }
\PYG{c}{! portion of the arrays.}
\PYG{c}{!}
\PYG{c}{! Each iteration, boundary values at the edge of each grid must be}
\PYG{c}{! exchanged with the neighbors.}


\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{jacobi1d\PYGZus{}mpi}
    \PYG{k}{use }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi}

    \PYG{k}{implicit }\PYG{k}{none}

\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k+kt}{integer}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{parameter} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{maxiter} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100000}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{nprint} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{5000}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{parameter} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{alpha} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{beta} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{6}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}

    \PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{iter}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{iend}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{itask}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{n}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ntasks}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{me}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{req1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{req2}
    \PYG{k+kt}{integer}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{dimension}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}STATUS\PYGZus{}SIZE}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{mpistatus}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{dimension}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{allocatable} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{f}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{uold}
    \PYG{k+kt}{real} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{kind} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kd}{::} \PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{dumax\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{dumax\PYGZus{}global}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{dx}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{tol}

    \PYG{c}{! Initialize MPI; get total number of tasks and ID of this task}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}comm\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ntasks}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}comm\PYGZus{}rank}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{me}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{c}{! Ask the user for the number of points}
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Input n ... "}
        \PYG{k}{read} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{n}
    \PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{if}
    \PYG{c}{! Broadcast to all tasks; everybody gets the value of n from task 0}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}bcast}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}INTEGER}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{n+nv}{dx} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n+nv}{tol} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.1}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nv}{dx}\PYG{o}{**}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}

    \PYG{c}{! Determine how many points to handle with each task}
    \PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{n} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{ntasks} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n+nv}{ntasks}
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}   \PYG{c}{! Only one task should print to avoid clutter}
        \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}task = "}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}task}
    \PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{if}

    \PYG{c}{! Determine start and end index for this task's points}
    \PYG{n+nv}{istart} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}task} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
    \PYG{n+nv}{iend} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{min}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nv}{points\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{n}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{c}{! Diagnostic: tell the user which points will be handled by which task}
    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'("Task ",i2," will take i = ",i6," through i = ",i6)'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
        \PYG{n+nv}{me}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{iend}


    \PYG{c}{! Initialize:}
    \PYG{c}{! -----------}

    \PYG{c}{! This makes the indices run from istart-1 to iend+1}
    \PYG{c}{! This is more or less cosmetic, but makes things easier to think about}
    \PYG{k}{allocate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{f}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nv}{iend}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nv}{iend}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nv}{iend}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{c}{! Each task sets its own, independent array}
    \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{iend}
        \PYG{c}{! Each task is a single thread with all its variables private}
        \PYG{c}{! so re-using the scalar variable x from one loop iteration to}
        \PYG{c}{! the next does not produce a race condition.}
        \PYG{n+nv}{x} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{dx}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{k+kt}{real}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nv}{f}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nb}{exp}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{p}{)}               \PYG{c}{! Source term}
        \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{alpha} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{x}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{beta} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{n+nv}{alpha}\PYG{p}{)}    \PYG{c}{! Initial guess}
    \PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{do}
    
    \PYG{c}{! Set boundary conditions if this task is keeping track of a boundary}
    \PYG{c}{! point}
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}        \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{alpha}
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{n+nv}{ntasks}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{iend}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}   \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{beta}


    \PYG{c}{! Jacobi iteratation:}
    \PYG{c}{! -------------------}

    \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{iter} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{maxiter}
        \PYG{n+nv}{uold} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{u}

        \PYG{c}{! Send endpoint values to tasks handling neighboring sections}
        \PYG{c}{! of the array.  Note that non-blocking sends are used; note}
        \PYG{c}{! also that this sends from uold, so the buffer we're sending}
        \PYG{c}{! from won't be modified while it's being sent.}
        \PYG{c}{!}
        \PYG{c}{! tag=1 is used for messages sent to the left}
        \PYG{c}{! tag=2 is used for messages sent to the right}

        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{\textgreater{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
            \PYG{c}{! Send left endpoint value to process to the "left"}
            \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}isend}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{req1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{if}
\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{\textless{}} \PYG{n+nv}{ntasks}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
            \PYG{c}{! Send right endpoint value to process on the "right"}
            \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}isend}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{iend}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{req2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{if}

        \PYG{c}{! Accept incoming endpoint values from other tasks.  Note that}
        \PYG{c}{! these are blocking receives, because we can't run the next step}
        \PYG{c}{! of the Jacobi iteration until we've received all the}
        \PYG{c}{! incoming data.}

        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{\textless{}} \PYG{n+nv}{ntasks}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
            \PYG{c}{! Receive right endpoint value}
            \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}recv}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{iend}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{mpistatus}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{if}
\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{\textgreater{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
            \PYG{c}{! Receive left endpoint value}
            \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}recv}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{mpistatus}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{if}

\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{n+nv}{dumax\PYGZus{}task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}   \PYG{c}{! Max seen by this task}

        \PYG{c}{! Apply Jacobi iteration on this task's section of the array}
        \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{iend}
            \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.5}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nv}{dx}\PYG{o}{**}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nv}{f}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n+nv}{dumax\PYGZus{}task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{max}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{dumax\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{abs}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{n+nv}{uold}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{do}

        \PYG{c}{! Take global maximum of dumax values}
        \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}allreduce}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{dumax\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{dumax\PYGZus{}global}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}DOUBLE\PYGZus{}PRECISION}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
            \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}MAX}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{c}{! Note that this MPI\PYGZus{}ALLREDUCE call acts as an implicit barrier,}
        \PYG{c}{! since no process can return from it until all processes}
        \PYG{c}{! have called it.  Because of this, after this call we know}
        \PYG{c}{! that all the send and receive operations initiated at the}
        \PYG{c}{! top of the loop have finished -- all the MPI\PYGZus{}RECV calls have}
        \PYG{c}{! finished in order for each process to get here, and if the}
        \PYG{c}{! MPI\PYGZus{}RECV calls have finished, the corresponding MPI\PYGZus{}ISEND}
        \PYG{c}{! calls have also finished.  Thus we can safely modify uold}
        \PYG{c}{! again.}

        \PYG{c}{! Also periodically report progress to the user}
        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{            }\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{mod}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{iter}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{nprint}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{==}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{                }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'("After ",i8," iterations, dumax = ",d16.6,/)'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                    \PYG{n+nv}{iter}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{dumax\PYGZus{}global}
            \PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{if}
\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{if}

        \PYG{c}{! All tasks now have dumax\PYGZus{}global, and can check for convergence}
        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{dumax\PYGZus{}global} \PYG{o}{\textless{}} \PYG{n+nv}{tol}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{exit}
\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{do}

\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'("Task number ",i2," finished after ",i9," iterations, dumax = ",\&}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{            e16.6)'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{me}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{iter}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{dumax\PYGZus{}global}


    \PYG{c}{! Output result:}
    \PYG{c}{! --------------}

    \PYG{c}{! Note: this only works if all processes share a file system}
    \PYG{c}{! and can all open and write to the same file!}

    \PYG{c}{! Synchronize to keep the next part from being non-deterministic}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}barrier}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{c}{! Have each task output to a file in sequence, using messages to}
    \PYG{c}{! coordinate}

    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}    \PYG{c}{! Task 0 goes first}
        \PYG{c}{! Open file for writing, replacing any previous version:}
        \PYG{k}{open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{unit}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{file}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"heatsoln.txt"}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{status}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"replace"}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{k}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"          x                  u"}
        \PYG{k}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'(2e20.10)'}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}    \PYG{c}{! Boundary value at left end}

        \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{iend}
            \PYG{k}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'(2e20.10)'}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nv}{dx}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{do}

\PYG{k}{        }\PYG{k}{close}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{unit}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{c}{! Closing the file should guarantee that all the ouput }
        \PYG{c}{! will be written to disk.}
        \PYG{c}{! If the file isn't closed before the next process starts writing,}
        \PYG{c}{! output may be jumbled or missing.}

        \PYG{c}{! Send go-ahead message to next task}
        \PYG{c}{! Only the fact that the message was sent is important, not its contents}
        \PYG{c}{! so we send the special address MPI\PYGZus{}BOTTOM and length 0.}
        \PYG{c}{! tag=4 is used for this message.}

        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ntasks} \PYG{o}{\textgreater{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{            }\PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}BOTTOM}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}INTEGER}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                          \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{k}{endif}

\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k}{else}
        \PYG{c}{! Wait for go-ahead message from previous task}
        \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}recv}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}BOTTOM}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}INTEGER}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                          \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{mpistatus}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{c}{! Open file for appending; do not destroy previous contents}
        \PYG{k}{open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{unit}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{file}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"heatsoln.txt"}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{status}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"old"}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{access}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"append"}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{k}{do }\PYG{n+nv}{i} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{istart}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{iend}
            \PYG{k}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'(2e20.10)'}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nv}{dx}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{i}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{do}

        \PYG{c}{! Boundary value at right end:}
        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{n+nv}{ntasks} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'(2e20.10)'}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.}\PYG{n+nv}{d0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{u}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{iend}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}    

        \PYG{c}{! Flush all pending writes to disk}
        \PYG{k}{close}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{unit}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{)}

        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{\textless{}} \PYG{n+nv}{ntasks} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{then}
            \PYG{c}{! Send go-ahead message to next task}
            \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}BOTTOM}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}INTEGER}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\&}
                          \PYG{n+nv}{MPI\PYGZus{}COMM\PYGZus{}WORLD}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{if}
\PYG{k}{    }\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{if}

    \PYG{c}{! Notify the user when all tasks have finished writing}
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{me} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{n+nv}{ntasks} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"Solution is in heatsoln.txt"}

    \PYG{c}{! Close out MPI}
    \PYG{k}{call }\PYG{n+nv}{mpi\PYGZus{}finalize}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{ierr}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k}{end }\PYG{k}{program }\PYG{n+nv}{jacobi1d\PYGZus{}mpi}
\end{Verbatim}

\section{Software Carpentry}
\label{software_carpentry:software-carpentry}\label{software_carpentry::doc}\label{software_carpentry:id1}
\href{http://software-carpentry.org}{Sofware Carpentry}
started out as a course at the University of Toronto
taught by Greg Wilson.  He has since left the university and turned this
into a major effort to help researchers be more productive by teaching them
basic computing skills.

Their ``boot camps'' are taught at many universities and other insitutions
around the world, check the \href{http://software-carpentry.org/bootcamps/index.html\#calendar}{calendar} to see if
one is coming up near you.

Some sections particularly relevant to this course, with links to videos:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\href{http://software-carpentry.org/4\_0/shell/}{The Shell}

\item {} 
\href{http://software-carpentry.org/4\_0/vc/}{Version Control}
(using Subversion -- svn)

\item {} 
\href{http://software-carpentry.org/4\_0/test/}{Testing}

\item {} 
\href{http://software-carpentry.org/4\_0/python/}{Python}

\item {} 
\href{http://software-carpentry.org/4\_0/sysprog/}{Systems Programming}
(from Python)

\item {} 
\href{http://software-carpentry.org/4\_0/oop/}{Classes and Objects}
(object oriented programming)

\item {} 
\href{http://software-carpentry.org/4\_0/make/}{Make}

\item {} 
\href{http://software-carpentry.org/4\_0/matrix/}{Matrix programming} (linear
algebra, NumPy)

\item {} 
\href{http://software-carpentry.org/4\_0/regexp/}{Regular expressions}

\end{itemize}
